node.description: Less fresh air, more tween shows.
node.content: ["As I interview parents for next week\u2019s newsletter about how everyone is faring during the pandemic\u2019s Omicron wave, there\u2019s a recurring theme: renewed anxiety about screen time. Families across the globe are dealing with quarantines because of coronavirus exposures or infections. After the Chicago teachers\u2019 union voted Tuesday not to report to school buildings over concerns about the city school district\u2019s preparedness for Omicron, classes have been canceled for the past three days. Friday, for the second time this week, several school districts in the Washington, D.C., area were closed or experienced delayed openings because of snow. But with the start of the new year, fewer parents seem to seem to have the flexibility to take time off from work, and so any prior limits they\u2019ve set about their kids\u2019 TV-watching or video game-playing have sort of gone down the drain.", "This is for sure happening in my house. My children watched what seemed like millions of hours of TV during the Christmas break, and when school resumed this week, at first we were successful in reverting to typical school-time rules: no TV until after dinner and homework is done, then unlimited TV until bedtime, which is usually one to two hours later.", "But my younger daughter came home early from school yesterday claiming she felt nauseous, and proceeded to (a) eat two pieces of toast and (b) play Nintendo for three straight hours. Either it was a fleeting malady or she scammed us (her coronavirus rapid test was negative). But whatever the cause of her return home, there wasn\u2019t really an alternative way for her to spend that time since her dad and I had work that couldn\u2019t wait, and she isn\u2019t old enough to read or entertain herself without a lot of parental involvement.", "I went to the American Academy of Pediatrics (A.A.P.) website to see how badly we were whiffing on their family media rules, and there\u2019s at least some flexibility in what it advises. There\u2019s an interactive section of the site where you can create your own family media plan, and we do OK on some parts: We keep phones, tablets and such out of our kids\u2019 room and away from the dining table. They\u2019re not allowed to chat with anyone they don\u2019t know.", "But we don\u2019t always \u201cco-view,\u201d a term A.A.P. uses for watching TV with your kids. It\u2019s partly that we\u2019re busy working, but also that the trashy tween shows they love are just about unwatchable. We occasionally persuade our kids to watch movies that we loved as children (getting them to watch the Winona Ryder version of \u201cLittle Women\u201d was a recent coup), but that\u2019s rare.", "I confess I don\u2019t feel that guilty about the state of screen time in our home right now. (Nor does my fellow Times Opinion newsletterer Jay Caspian Kang, who wrote a great piece this week for The Times Magazine about a 10-year-old YouTube star raking in millions of dollars playing with toys.) After all, many recommendations from pediatricians and other experts don\u2019t take pandemics into account. Case in point: an excellent story by Anya Kamenetz that The Times ran in the summer of 2020 with the headline \u201cI Was a Screen-Time Expert. Then the Coronavirus Happened.\u201d", "She acknowledges that much of the old advice that she gave now falls somewhere between unworkable and inapplicable, and she advises parents to focus on their kids\u2019 feelings rather than obsessing about the precise number of hours spent on screens. As it becomes clearer that one byproduct of the pandemic is a children\u2019s mental health crisis, Kamenetz\u2019s advice is even more relevant.", "This bit, in particular, resonates with me as I muddle through this month, which is already feeling endless just a week in:", "As I head into another frigid weekend of trying to avoid Omicron, I\u2019m stocking up on craft supplies and kid-friendly recipes we can make together (the pizza recipe from J. Kenji L\u00f3pez-Alt\u2019s book \u201cEvery Night Is Pizza Night\u201d is a family favorite). But I\u2019m also accepting that my kids may just become really, really good at Mario Kart this winter.", "If you want a chance to get your Tiny Victory published, find us on Instagram @NYTparenting and use the hashtag #tinyvictories; email us; or enter your Tiny Victory at the bottom of this page.
